entry.name: Identification of Targets of c-Src Tyrosine Kinase by Chemical Complementation and Phospho-proteomics
entry.description: TRANCHE KEY: TzGvo1FbhJkLaM/FDLKTewGrBYDqWRPO/Oe9KHmXiohZonXBuLlolUe2NuY4G/UIubBhNQjySdOasclB3Os1vYmje8gAAAAAAAAJtw== Original data file: Isabel-2stateSILAC-Agstain_merge.mgf. Folder: Isabel_2stateSILAC_Agstain. From Tranche: {{i}}The cellular proto-oncogene c-Src is a non-receptor protein tyrosine kinase (PTK) involved in cell growth and cytoskeletal regulation but its precise functions in cell signaling are complex and not fully understood. Identification of c-Src-s PTK cellular substrates remains a major challenge as there is no simple way to directly stimulate its activity without triggering a range of other signaling pathways. Here we combine the chemical rescue of transfected mutant R390A c-Src in Src-deficient mouse embryonic fibroblasts (SYF cells) and mass spectrometry-based phosphoproteomics to analyze the range of tyrosine phosphorylation events that occur in the cell upon rapid stimulation of c-Src PTK activity. Dozens of previously uncharacterized c-Src protein targets and putative phosphorylation sites have been identified, many of which play key roles in signaling and cytoskeletal networks, particularly cell adhesion. One of these c-Src targets, C3G, a small G-protein guanine nucleotide exchange factor, was further investigated, and the effects of c-Src on spatial and temporal C3G activation of its target, Rap1, were revealed. These results provide a strategy for obtaining a comprehensive understanding of the functions of non-receptor tyrosine kinases in cell signaling with high kinetic resolution.{{/i}}
